intro: Leandra atroviridis, commonly known as the black-veined leandra, is a species of flowering plant native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its dark green, velvety leaves with prominent black veins, giving it its common name. Its flowers are typically white or pale yellow, with five petals and a showy, trumpet-shaped structure. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is adapted to grow in moist, shaded environments.
